author: A_Brickset_user
title: Rock Island Refuge Rocks!
review: With all the commotion over the new pirate legos, I thought I would take the opportunity to review one of my favorite pirate sets of all time --- The Rock Island Refuge.  As pirate bases go, it was definately the biggest, using the same baseplate as the Eldorado Fortress.  It also has an additional blue plate that juts out pretty far to act as water.  The structure itself is awesome!  It has a nice long dock with castle fortifications at one end to protect the cannon.  The structure itself has two levels, all created from black bricks and resembling some old ruins.  There is a trapdoor to put the treasure in, and a jail cell to lock up the soldiers.  Taking the steps up to the second level, there is a cookstove, as well as ship rigging and TWO rope bridges to get around the fortress.  In front of the structure is two story tower with a crane for loading large amounts of treasure.  The figure selection is pretty good and the playabilty is awesome! I especially liked the little raft that came with it (it is probably the nicest raft in the Pirate Collection behind "Raft Raiders.") The entire fortress feels like a more finalized version of the "Forbidden Island" lego set. My only complaint is that it should have had one more cannon.  I have found that it makes the perfect pirate base for my pirate wars.

author: hustla187
title: A Classic Pirates Set
review: If Lego should've released another Pirates set, it might be this one. I like this because it's a set that can you can play with for hours and not get bored of it. You get an island, boat, raft, rope bridges, palm trees, minifigs, and so much more. This is a great set and the 2009 sets should be just like this.

author: SimonStickfish
title: Brilliant!
review:
I finally found it on Ebay for a reasonable price. The only thing that was wrong with it was that it had a black/white sail for the soldier's boat, instead of the blue one. That alone makes this set very rare: to my knowledge, this is the only set that has a blue small sail. I don't have this rare blue sail, but that's not a disaster ;-).

It's big, it has a cannon, it has boats, soldiers and pirates. Also very nice is the quite rare female pirate, found in not so many sets. Get one if you can!

author: _obelix_
title: The BEST Pirate Base
review:
One of my first and definitely favourite sets of all time. This set is, to my knowledge, the largest pirate base set, the second being the Skull Island. It has everything you would expect of a base, a large, well designed fortress with hanging bridges, a large basement for storage, a prison, a small dock, with a possibility of docking an entire ship ( which greatly increases its playability ) the BEST RAFT I've ever seen, a small boat , great number of quality minifigs both pirates and soldiers, parrot, monkey and many more...

All in all, 5 out of 5

author: CCOOK
title: Pirate HQ
review:
This is a nice-looking set with a lot to offer, and has a dock for the Barracuda as well.

I actually do not own this set, but was able to build it using Peeron instructions for the set; I used the El Dorado Fortress base + the base from the Wolfpack tower and some other castle components that I had left over, and this set was very easy to build - I basically looked at the instructions and then dug through bins for about 45 minutes until I had a giant pile of black castle parts and palm tree branches - it only took me about an hour and a half to build the set - glad I didn't.  Basically all you need is some black castles, two large rope ladders, two plastic bridges, and you're all set.  There's only one really unique piece in the set that is not commonly found elsewhere, and it's the steep-sloped 2x2x3 corner roof brick that's used as a chimney for a stove that's on the second floor of the structure.

Anyway, the set is a good place to park the Barracuda, and is wide open for modification with more palm trees and newer parts.

author: AETerry
title: Rock Island Refuge Review
review:
In many ways I often felt that this was a revist to Forbidden Island, only Lego was going all out to truely make an Island Headquarters for the Pirates. Regardless, this set is an amazing one and well worth getting.

 

The base plate is the same as featured for the Eldorado Fortress and King's Mountian Fortress sets with a small blue plate attached to create an area for more water and really support the dock area.

 

There are seven minifigures in all, eight when you count the monkey. Captain Redbeard who's fairly common, an uncommon red capped female pirate, 3 male pirates and 2 Imperial Minifigures. Plus a shark and parrot.

 

The main set is chalked full of features that Forbidden Island had originally only hinted at. There's more rope bridges, rope ladders, crane to move barrels on and off the Pirate's raft or rowboats. A dungeon for keeping intruding Imperial Soldiers in. Palm Tree, a proper dock for the Pirates to leave or docks their boats at.

 

There's a Pirates raft included, which with other rafts I've seen, this is already. The Soldiers have a small sail boat with a blue sail & mast that they come to the island on. Yes you can argue this beats out Forbidden Island with all it's features, but it's a second, later model.

author: Ernst
title: Forbidden Island on a raised baseplate but ok.
review:
Overall 4 bricks : Lego used the raised baseplate to make an improved (??) or expanded version of Forbidden Island I think. It is a good set but maybe they exaggerated a bit by trying to put in too much extra's. Still it turned out to be a good looking set with a lot of nice features, sufficient minifigures and great playability although no price for originality. A bit overpriced maybe but probably because it is not easy to find.

 

Building 4 bricks : A nice set to built with a mix of Castle and Pirate pieces. It is not too hard to built this set, the mix of wall parts and small bricks give a nice building as result. Although I must add it is not a real building, more a defence hideout. On the left side a nice scaffold with canon with a small defence wall. For the Pirates you built a small raft with strange small sails, the Imperial Soldiers have boat with a real sail. The crane is a bit simple too, no possibilty to move it up or down and no winch. Overall a solid and good looking result, the green leafes give it a bit of a ruin look

 

Parts 5 bricks : The set offers 7 minifigures with sufficient weapons, a nice female Pirate, a parrot, a shark and a monkey. Other good parts are the 2 bridges, the stairs, the raised baseplate of course and overall a lot of usefull (Castle) parts. Also a lot of small banners and flags and the "Imperial" sail.

 

Playability 5 bricks : the set offers huge playabilty thanks to its looks, the boat and raft, the 7 minifigures and the total setup. Really nothing is missing for hours of fun.

 

Value 4 bricks : The average "sold" price on Bricklink is some €60,00 which is I think in order. Considering the quantity of parts maybe a bit high but since it seems to be a rare set and the playing possibilities probably justifiable. I paid less so for me the deal was fine.

author: SirSven7
title: Lego Steve's Review
review:
The Largest set released in 1991 is also the largest pirate base available, it featured every single available minfig from the pirate range except one (Governor Broadside), this alone shows how much effort Lego put into creating variety in there early sets. Another example of this is shown with the inclusion of the second smaller base plate, very little is actually attached to this plate but its inclusion make the whole set look a lot more together. Also featured in this set is the first and only small blue sail and a nice pirate raft (though not as good as the Castaway’s Raft 6257 in 1989). The structure to this set is not quite as good if compared to the Eldorado Fortress but if we consider that this place is being manned by rough Pirates and not disciplined Soldiers then the differences make a lot of sense, it is meant to look a little delipadated. Overall though I feel that this set is just missing that little extra detail that made other sets great, the structure is not as exciting as Eldorado Fortress, which in turn make the set less engaging from a construction viewpoint, it just lacked that little something. Still though that is not to say the set is bad in any way it just had the potential to be more.

If you like this review click on the link to find it and all reviews of the pirate sets

http://legosteveblog.blogspot.com/2011/03/lego-pirates-wave-in-1989.html
